Title:
Morphological, phylogenetic characterization and biofilm
formation of Neoscytalidium oculus sp.nov. (Botryosphaeriaceae) from
first report of keratitis isolate in México
Keywords:
Fungal keratitis, Case report, Morphology and phylogenetic
identification, Neoscytalidium oculus sp. nov., Biofilm, Fungal biofilm
formation
Abstract:
Opportunistic fungi frequently cause human mycotic
keratitis. Neoscytalidium spp. is a saprophytic crop pathogen, but in
recent years some strains have been isolated from human body. In this
study, we report as first time a fungi strain obtained from a patient
with cornea ulcer and identified as Neoscytalidium. Morphological
observations on conidiogenous cells and molecular/phylogenetic analysis
reveals a new specie identity, Neoscytalidium oculus sp. nov. Optimal
conditions for biofilm formation were obtained at a concentration of
1x106 conidia/ml, during 96 h at 28°C. Micrographs from optical
microscopy confirmed biofilm formation. This is the first report in
Latin America in which a new species of Neoscytalidium genus from
clinical isolation had been identified. The biofilm model developed
constitute a novel aspect of Neoscytalidium virulence, which could be
involved in human infections
